meta.title: Amtrak Focus Groups
meta.participant_profile: The bulk of both groups will consist of "informed voters" (high-propensity voters), with at least one quarter consisting of experts (e.g., congressional staff, transportation experts, mid-to-senior level federal staff, etc.). Group 1: Republican (and potentially Republican-leaning Independents). Group 2: Democratic (and potentially Democratic-leaning Independents).
meta.routing_note: Content without highlighting applies to both groups. Democratic-only content is explicitly routed in sections below.

sections.title: Welcome & Opening Comments + Consent
sections.script_md: Good evening and welcome to our focus group session. Thank you for taking the time to join us this evening. My name is Justin Wallin, and I run a research organization that works throughout the nation. Our goal tonight is to have an open discussion about your perceptions about some topics that may be important to your communities. You were invited because you are a voter, who is considered to be relatively informed about public policy issues. Our discussion this evening will be audio and video-taped… For privacy reasons, we will address each other by the letters and/or numbers on your tile. Understanding this, may I quickly confirm that it is all right with each of you to record this discussion? Everyone please signify your permission by saying, 'yes' as I call your name. Your participation in this group is entirely voluntary, and you are free to leave at any point if you absolutely must. However, only those who participate in the entire session will receive the incentive following the session. This discussion is conducted for research purposes only—no one will try to sell you anything.

questions.text: As I call your label, please say 'yes' to consent to recording.

sections.title: Discussion Group Ground Rules
sections.script_md: First, since each person's comments are important, only one person speaks at a time. Please direct all comments toward me and speak up. Your participation is very important and side conversations are distracting—please keep focused. There's no such thing as a wrong answer—share honest views, positive or negative. If you agree or disagree, please elaborate and tell us why. We'll move the conversation along at times to cover everything. My role is not to express opinions, but I may press a little and bring up ideas to react to.

questions.text: Does everyone understand and agree to these ground rules?

sections.title: Warm-up
sections.script_md: Now, let's find out some more about each other. I'll call your designation—please very briefly and generally introduce yourself (no specific organizations).

questions.text: Share your role in general terms and why you joined today.
How important do you feel our nation's infrastructure—including roads, bridges, power and water—should be for our nation's leaders to prioritize? Why or why not?
How important do you feel protecting and improving our environment should be for our nation's leaders to prioritize? Why or why not?
Do you feel that passenger rail is an important part of our nation's infrastructure? Why or why not?
Do you feel that America lags behind other countries or regions, such as Europe or China, in providing rail service? Should this gap be closed?

questions.script_md: Let me provide some context about Amtrak: The National Railroad Passenger Corporation operates 21,000 route miles across 46 states, DC, and 3 Canadian provinces. They run over 300 trains daily, with speeds up to 150 mph, serving more than 500 destinations. In 2019, Amtrak carried 32.5 million riders—approximately 89,000 per day.

questions.text: What do you think of Amtrak in general—do you approve or disapprove? Why?
Is Amtrak an important part of national infrastructure, just like roads and bridges? How important is it? Why or why not?

Currently, Amtrak's network serves over 525 locations nationwide. Amtrak has proposed an expansion to serve 160 additional communities and bring new rail corridors to 25 new states. The federal government would need to invest approximately $75 billion over 15 years for stations, equipment, and infrastructure. Given this information, how do you feel about federal investment in expanding Amtrak service?
What are the main benefits you see from expanding Amtrak service? What concerns do you have?
The expansion is projected to create over 500,000 new jobs, including approximately 3,000 Amtrak workforce jobs. How important is job creation as a reason to invest in Amtrak expansion?

Amtrak's electrified Northeast Corridor trains emit 83% less greenhouse gases than driving alone and 73% less than flying. Traveling by Amtrak is 47% more energy efficient than driving and one-third more efficient than flying. How important are these environmental benefits?

In many urban areas, the average commuter loses more than 40 hours per year to highway traffic delays—equivalent to a week of vacation. Expanding passenger rail could reduce traffic congestion. How important is reducing traffic congestion as a benefit?

Expansion to the South and Southwest would bring rail access to underserved communities and support minority-owned businesses. How important is addressing equity and social justice in this investment?
Overall, given everything we've discussed, do you support or oppose federal investment in expanding Amtrak service? Why?
Which of the key benefits—job creation, environmental impact, traffic congestion reduction, or social justice—do you feel is MOST important? Why?
Is there anything else you'd like to share about Amtrak or passenger rail investment that we haven't discussed?

questions.script_md: Thank you very much for participating in this discussion. Your insights and feedback are extremely valuable to our research. You'll receive your incentive as you leave. We really appreciate your time and contribution today.
